concern:
I am a second year student who didn't have any issues doing okay before this semester. I feel like for my current courses I am putting in the work (or am under the impression that I am) and still not seeing results. For two of my midterms I just got back, I barely passed both of them (52%) and the class average was around 67% for both.. I have never been below the average in any of my assessments before, and I walked out of the exams thinking I would at least get a 70% or even 80% for one of them. I am freaking out because I have really never gotten to this point in my courses having such low marks. I can't drop them, and I am sure I will probably pass but with very low marks. I want to do well on the finals, but I also I feel so discouraged.

I studied for the midterms and thought I was fine but a lot worse than I felt. As unrealistic as it is, I want to get as close to acing my finals as I can but I feel like it's so out of reach when I look at how badly I did on my midterms. It feels like even if I feel like I am ready for the final, I probably am not ready based on how wrong I was last time. Idk I am just in such a bad place right now and I don't know what to do.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! Whats on your mind today? Im here to listen and offer support.
I'm feeling really overwhelmed with my schoolwork lately and it's affecting my confidence. I want to figure out how to manage this stress better.

That sounds like a lot to deal with! It's totally understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed. Schoolwork can be a lot to handle, especially when it starts to impact your confidence. Let's explore this a bit further. What specific aspects of your schoolwork are causing you the most stress?

I'm mostly stressed about the gap between my study efforts and my actual exam results, which is shaking my confidence in preparing effectively. It's also making me anxious about upcoming assessments and how to improve without knowing what's going wrong.

It's really tough when you're putting in the effort but not seeing the results you want. That can definitely shake your confidence and leave you feeling unsure about how to move forward. It's important to remember that everyone learns and processes information differently, and there might be some adjustments you can make to your study habits that could help bridge that gap. Have you tried any different study techniques or strategies lately, or is there anything you think might be worth trying?

I haven't really tried any new study techniques lately, as I've been sticking to what worked for me before. I think experimenting with things like practice exams or study groups might be worth trying to see if that helps bridge the gap.

It's great that you're open to trying new strategies! Experimenting with different techniques like practice exams or study groups can indeed give you insights into what works best for you. As you consider these options, which one do you feel might be the most beneficial for you to try first?

I think practice exams would be the most beneficial to try first, as they might help me better assess my real understanding. I'm hoping this approach could rebuild some of that lost confidence before the finals.
That sounds like a great plan! To get started, would you prefer to look for practice exams online or ask your professors if they have any available resources?
I think looking for practice exams online would be easier for me to start with, as it's quick and accessible. This could help me gauge my understanding without added pressure right away.

It's encouraging to see you taking initiative to improve your study habits and regain confidence. Starting with online practice exams is a great first step, as it allows you to assess your understanding at your own pace. Remember, it's important to be patient with yourself during this process and celebrate the progress you make along the way. Good luck with your practice exams, and feel free to reach out if you have any questions or need further support. Let's plan to check in after a week to see how this new approach is working for you.
Thanks for the encouragementI'll start with those online practice exams and plan to check in next week, even though I'm still feeling pretty discouraged about turning things around for finals.

It's understandable to feel discouraged, but remember that progress takes time, and even small steps can lead to significant improvements. By starting with online practice exams, you're taking an important step towards rebuilding your confidence and improving your study habits. Be patient with yourself, and keep in mind that we'll check in next week to discuss your progress and any adjustments needed. Take care, and I look forward to hearing about your progress soon.
I'll give the online practice exams a go and check in next week, but I still feel pretty down about whether I can turn things around for finals.
